title: Game Preview: Calgary Flames @ Pittsburgh Penguins 1/10/26
description: Who: Calgary Flames (18-22-4, 40 points, 7th place Pacific Division) @ Pittsburgh Penguins (21-12-9, 51 points, 4th place Metropolitan Division) When: 3:30 p.m. eastern How to Watch: Broadcast locally Sportsnet Pittsburgh and SN/TVAS, streaming on ESPN+ Pens’ Path Ahead: The busy stretch continues tomorrow with a 5 p.m. ET game in Boston.
fullText:
Who: Calgary Flames (18-22-4, 40 points, 7th place Pacific Division) @ Pittsburgh Penguins (21-12-9, 51 points, 4th place Metropolitan Division)

How to Watch: Broadcast locally Sportsnet Pittsburgh and SN/TVAS, streaming on ESPN+

Pens’ Path Ahead: The busy stretch continues tomorrow with a 5 p.m. ET game in Boston. Then it’s back to Pittsburgh for three home games next week, starting with the Tampa Bay Lightning on Tuesday and followed by division matchups against the Philadelphia Flyers and Columbus Blue Jackets on Thursday and Saturday, respectively.

Opponent Track: It’s been a dispiriting stretch in Calgary. The Flames are on a four-game losing skid, and they’ve been held to just one goal in each of their last three games (while getting outscored by a total of 18-3). Calgary most recently dropped a back-to-back set in Montreal and Boston earlier this week.

Season Series: This is the first time the Flames and Pens have met this season. They’ll see one another later this month, when the Pens head to Calgary on Jan. 21 as part of a four-game West Coast road swing.

Hidden Stat: The Flames are heading into this matchup with the worst road points percentage in the NHL, going 6-15-2 (.304 points percentage) in 23 away games so far this season.

Hidden Stat II: Courtesy of Pens PR, the Penguins are 13-1-4 in games where at least one member of the current fourth line (Connor Dewar, Blake Lizotte and Noel Acciari) records a point.

Jonathan Huberdeau – Nazem Kadri – Joel Farabee

Blake Coleman – Mikael Backlund – Matt Coronato

Connor Zary – Morgan Frost – Yegor Sharangovich

Ryan Lomberg – Justin Kirkland – Adam Klapka

Yan Kuznetsov / MacKenzie Weegar

Joel Hanley / Hunter Brzustewicz

Goalies: Dustin Wolf, Devin Cooley

Potential scratches: Zayne Parekh (day-to-day upper body injury), William Stromgren, Brayden Pachal

Injured Reserve: Jake Bean, Samuel Honk, John Beecher, Martin Pospisil

Flames fans haven’t gotten to see rookie defenseman Zayne Parekh since he set a record for Canadian World Juniors defensemen with 13 points in seven games of the 2025 tournament. The 19-year-old was sidelined for Calgary’s back-to-back earlier this week.

Dustin Wolf has made eight straight starts for the Flames, including in the team’s losses to the Habs and Bruins on consecutive days last week. Backup Devin Cooley has been dealing with an illness, according to head coach Ryan Huska, who admitted it has not been “ideal” to be playing Wolf this much. Whether Wolf (3-5-0 over this stretch) gets a ninth straight start against the Pens could depend on Cooley’s health status.

The Flames are about to hit a crossroads at the trade deadline. Right now, they’re in no man’s land. They’re ostensibly still in the playoff race (six points back of a Western Conference Wild Card spot with 38 games left in the season). They had a resurgent December (9-4-0) before their January slump (0-4).

They’re playing veterans and keeping young players on a tight leash— rookie winger William Stromgren made his NHL debut on Wednesday, but skated just over eight minutes before getting scratched for Thursday’s matchup with the Bruins.

The Flames are also the lowest-scoring team in the NHL with 2.13 goals for per game, and they’re allowing the fifth-most goals against (3.57 per game). The Calgary power play is ticking along at just 12.5 percent.

Blake Coleman has been tied to the Montreal Canadiens by TSN’s Pierre LeBrun. Rasmus Andersson is an obvious trade chip given that he’s playing on an expiring contract. Whether these players and others ultimately get moved at the deadline could depend at least in part on how soon the Flames can end their ongoing losing streak.

Infographic courtesy of Pens PR

Rickard Rakell – Sidney Crosby – Bryan Rust

Evgeni Malkin – Ben Kindel – Yegor Chinakhov

Anthony Mantha – Tommy Novak – Justin Brazeau

Connor Dewar – Blake Lizotte – Noel Acciari

Parker Wotherspoon / Erik Karlsson

Goalies: Stuart Skinner and Arturs Silovs

Potential Scratches: Ville Koivunen, Kevin Hayes, Connor Clifton

IR: Filip Hallander, Caleb Jones, Rutger McGroarty

The Penguins had an optional practice Friday ahead of today’s afternoon game and this weekend’s back-to-back set, per Michelle Crechiolo.

Muse called this a "get what you need" day. 

"We had things set up for everybody… for guys that felt like they needed to get on the ice, with the afternoon game tomorrow, they had that option. For other guys, it's getting in the gym, getting activation, getting treatments." https://t.co/DnIAfwy7QC

— Pens Inside Scoop (@PensInsideScoop) January 9, 2026

Malkin made his return from injury on Ben Kindel’s wing during Thursday’s win over the Devils. We’ll see if he sticks on the wing or returns to his natural center position for his second game back.

Only the Tampa Bay Lightning (eight straight wins) are currently riding a longer victory streak than the Pens (six consecutive victories).

Since the NHL's holiday break concluded, the Penguins lead the league in wins (6), points (12), goals per game (4.83), goals against (13) and goal differential (+16). pic.twitter.com/N4ROFPqsri

— Penguins PR (@PenguinsPR) January 9, 2026

title: Steelers $10 million defender named top cut candidate
description: The Steelers’ linebacker could be released
fullText:
The Pittsburgh Steelers signed linebacker Malik Harrison last offseason to a two-year, $10 million deal, which was a signing that came with some annoyance from the fan base. It wasn’t so much a jab at Harrison, but he was signed while the Steelers let Elandon Roberts leave in free agency.

While the Steelers have a wild card game to look forward to on Monday, Over The Cap released its list of 100 cut candidates, and Harrison made the list for Pittsburgh. None of his 2026 salary is guaranteed, and the Steelers could look elsewhere for more productive depth at the position. He finished the regular season with 28 tackles.

The Steelers will look to end their playoff-win drought on Monday night. Should they lose to Houston, that streak reaches nine seasons without a playoff win.

Be sure to bookmark Behind the Steel Curtain for all the latest news, breakdowns, and more!

title: WVU hosts No. 22 Kansas in sold-out Big 12 matchup in Morgantown
description: West Virginia hosts No. 22 Kansas for a sold-out noon tip as both teams look to gain early traction in Big 12 play. Here’s everything you need to know about the matchup and how to watch.
fullText:
Date: Saturday, January 10, 2026

Location: Hope Coliseum — Morgantown, West Virginia

Announcers: Brandon Gaudin and LaPhonso Ellis

Streaming: FOX Sports (TV provider login required)

Radio: Mountaineer Sports Network (Radio Affiliates) | SiriusXM Channel 380 and Streaming Channel 970 | WVU Gameday App (Apple | Android)

Radio Announcers: Tony Caridi (PBP) and Brad Howe (analyst)

Reminder: It is against site policy to post links to illegal streams in the comments.

Get in on the action with our friends at FanDuel Sportsbook.

West Virginia: +3.5 points | +158 ML

(As of 12:30AM ET/January 10, 2026)

West Virginia is back at home this afternoon, hosting Kansas after picking up a 62–60 win over Cincinnati earlier this week. The Mountaineers (10–5, 1–1) had to mount a late comeback to get through that one, but they pulled it off and avoided an 0–2 start to Big 12 play.

Honor Huff carried the offense against the Bearcats with 24 points, knocking down six threes, while Treysen Eaglestaff provided what would be the game winner with a late three that put WVU back in front for good. Chance Moore added 14 off the bench, continuing to give the Mountaineers a reliable presence when the offense needed a jolt. WVU shot well from the perimeter, though rebounding and second chances again became an issue during extended stretches.

Kansas comes to Morgantown at 11–4 overall and 1–1 in Big 12 play. The Jayhawks dropped their opener at UCF before rallying from a 16-point deficit to beat TCU, 104-101, in overtime earlier this week. Overall, they’re averaging 77.7 points per game while shooting 47 percent from the floor.

Freshman guard Darryn Peterson has been the star of the show. After returning from a hamstring injury, Peterson scored 26 and 32 points in his last two games and is averaging 22.5 points in limited action. Ross Hodge noted this week that Peterson doesn’t need much help to create offense, which puts pressure on the entire defensive group to stay disciplined over long stretches.

Kansas isn’t short on help around him. Tre White, Flory Bidunga, and Melvin Council Jr. all average double figures and give the Jayhawks multiple options when possessions break down. Kansas has been most comfortable when games open up, particularly when they’re able to score before defenses are set.

New, improved notifications system!

Comment on articles, community posts

Saturday’s game will be the 30th meeting between West Virginia and Kansas since the Mountaineers joined the Big 12 in 2013. The series has produced a number of close finishes and notable moments, particularly in Morgantown, where WVU holds a 7–5 record against the Jayhawks.

West Virginia has won two straight in the series, including last season’s 62–61 victory at Allen Fieldhouse and a 91–85 win in Morgantown two years ago. Other home highlights include a 91–79 win in 2021 and buzzer-beaters in 2015 and 2019. WVU’s largest margin of victory came in 2017, a 16-point win during the “Press Virginia” era against a Kansas team ranked No. 2 nationally.

Kansas has more ways to score, especially if Darryn Peterson is comfortable early. West Virginia has generally played well defensively at home, but they’ve also had stretches where the offense slows and extra possessions creep in.

If WVU can avoid long dry spells, this should stay tight into the second half. Kansas’ depth shows up late more often than not, and that’s usually enough to create some separation.

title: Baggio: Three Italy World Cup eliminations ‘not easy to digest’
description: Italy legend Roberto Baggio still carries a ‘weight’ for missing a decisive penalty kick against Brazil in the 1994 World Cup Final: ‘I lost three World Cups on penalties, not easy to digest.’...
fullText:
Italy legend Roberto Baggio still carries a ‘weight’ for missing a decisive penalty kick against Brazil in the 1994 World Cup Final: ‘I lost three World Cups on penalties, not easy to digest.’

Italy legend Baggio said his penalty kick miss in the 1994 World Cup Final was “the greatest bitterness of my football career.”

“I grew up with the dream of a World Cup Final against Brazil. I don’t have a clear memory of why this goal has stayed with me since I was very young, through my entire life,” Baggio told Forbes Italia via Gazzetta.

“I have always considered myself an ordinary person. Just like everyone else. I never saw myself as special. I only had this uncontrollable passion for football. A passion that stirs something inside you from morning to night. I slept with the ball.

Italian former football player Roberto Baggio (R) and Argentine-born Italian former football player, David Trezeguet (L) gesture before the beginning of the Argentina 2023 U-20 World Cup final match between Uruguay and Italy at the Estadio Unico Diego Armando Maradona stadium in La Plata, Argentina, on June 11, 2023. (Photo by Alejandro PAGNI / AFP) (Photo by ALEJANDRO PAGNI/AFP via Getty Images)

“I would have given up everything else to win that World Cup. I was representing Italy. It was the goal I was always chasing. The last thought before going to sleep was how to win that World Cup. Maybe by scoring a bicycle kick.

“Then it turned out in a way I never would have imagined, and I will never be able to forget it. Just one step away from the finish line. The greatest bitterness of my football career, an unbelievable personal tragedy, I still carry that weight inside me.”

FLORENCE, ITALY – JUNE 03: Roberto Baggio looks on during a press conference at Centro Tecnico Federale di Coverciano on June 03, 2024 in Florence, Italy. (Photo by Claudio Villa/Getty Images)

Baggio took part in three World Cups. The Azzurri finished third in 1990, runners-up in 1994 and were eliminated in the quarter-finals by eventual winners France in 1998.

“I played in three World Cups. In Italy [1990], we finished third, winning six matches and drawing one. I lost three World Cups on penalties, not easy to digest,” he concluded.

title: Inter eye move for Bassey but Fulham make January transfer decision – report
description: Reports in the UK suggest that Inter are among the Serie A clubs interested in versatile Fulham defender Calvin Bassey, but the Premier League side don’t want to sell the Nigerian this month.TeamTal...
fullText:
Reports in the UK suggest that Inter are among the Serie A clubs interested in versatile Fulham defender Calvin Bassey, but the Premier League side don’t want to sell the Nigerian this month.

TeamTalk reports that Inter are among the Serie A clubs interested in Fulham defender Bassey.

MILAN, ITALY – SEPTEMBER 30: FC Internazionale team line up during the UEFA Champions League 2025/26 League Phase MD2 match between FC Internazionale Milano and SK Slavia Praha at Stadio San Siro on September 30, 2025 in Milan, Italy. (Photo by Marco Luzzani/Getty Images)

The Nerazzurri are expected to make big changes in central defence over the coming months, given that Francesco Acerbi and Stefan de Vrij are expected to leave at the end of their contracts in June.

MILAN, ITALY – DECEMBER 09: Francesco Acerbi of FC Internazionale lies injured during the UEFA Champions League 2025/26 League Phase MD6 match between FC Internazionale Milano and Liverpool FC at Stadio San Siro on December 09, 2025 in Milan, Italy. (Photo by Marco Luzzani/Getty Images)

According to the report, Inter and other unnamed Serie A clubs are tracking Bassey’s situation, but Fulham are unwilling to sell their defender this month.

MANCHESTER, ENGLAND – MARCH 02: Calvin Bassey of Fulham celebrates scoring his team’s first goal with teammates Timothy Castagne (L) and Adama Traore (R) during the Emirates FA Cup Fifth Round match between Manchester United and Fulham at Old Trafford on March 02, 2025 in Manchester, England. (Photo by Justin Setterfield/Getty Images)

Bassey has scored one goal in 18 appearances across all competitions this season and is a pivotal member of the team, whom Fulham don’t want to sell midway through the season.

Therefore, any potential move might only happen in the summer, when Inter will still be looking for at least one new centre-back.

title: Inter Milan To Make Key Selection Choice For Napoli Clash Today As Defender Heads For Potential Exit
description: Inter face Napoli with Cristian Chivu expected to make a final call on his defence, while Francesco Acerbi remains part of the discussion ahead of a possible exit.According to Tuttosport, Inter are le...
fullText:
Inter face Napoli with Cristian Chivu expected to make a final call on his defence, while Francesco Acerbi remains part of the discussion ahead of a possible exit.

According to Tuttosport, Inter are leaning toward fielding the same starting XI that beat Atalanta and Bologna, continuing with a settled structure for the San Siro showdown.

That would confirm Manuel Akanji in the centre of defence and Piotr Zielinski in midfield.

Therefore with Yann Bisseck and Alessandro Bastoni completing the back three.

However, the decision is not yet locked in.

The newspaper reports that Chivu will only make his definitive choice today, or even during the pre-match warm-up on Sunday morning.

MILAN, ITALY – NOVEMBER 09: Francesco Acerbi of Internazionale warms up prior to the Serie A match between FC Internazionale and SS Lazio at Giuseppe Meazza Stadium on November 09, 2025 in Milan, Italy. (Photo by Marco Luzzani/Getty Images)

Acerbi remains an alternative option, and a reshuffle involving Akanji cannot be ruled out at this stage.

Elsewhere, there are no major doubts.

Inter are expected to stick with continuity across the rest of the lineup.

Therefore prioritising stability for a fixture that could prove decisive in the title race.

There is also positive news from the bench.

Both Andy Diouf and Matteo Darmian are set to return to the matchday squad after recovering their fitness.

Indeed, offering Chivu additional depth.

Get the final details right, trust recent momentum, and deliver a statement performance against Napoli.

title: How to watch Ohio State vs. Washington: TV, live stream info, storylines for Sunday's game
description: The Buckeyes continue their West Coast swing in Seattle.
fullText:
Making a push for its first NCAA Tournament appearance in five years, Ohio State will play Washington on the road Sunday in a Big Ten matchup on Peacock.

The Buckeyes (3-2 Big Ten, 11-4 overall) are on a West Coast road swing that opened Thursday with a 72-62 victory over Oregon. Ohio State, which was picked to finish ninth in a preseason conference media poll, averaged a 25-point margin of victory during a six-game winning streak earlier this season.

The Huskies (1-3 Big Ten, 9-6 overall) are starting a tough three-game homestand against the Midwestern stalwarts of the Big Ten. After Ohio State, Washington will welcome No. 2 Michigan and No. 12 Michigan State next week.

Washington leads 8-5 over Ohio State in the series, including a 6-0 record in Seattle.

More information below on Ohio State and Washington and how to watch the game.

The Buckeyes feature an efficient offense that ranks in the top 25 nationally in field goal percentage (50.6) and is fifth in the Big Ten at 84.6 points per game. Ohio State also makes 78.4% of its free throws (eighth in the country) but struggles from distance, converting only 34.3% of its 3-pointers.

In the win over Oregon, all five starters scored in double figures. Devin Royal and Christoph Tilly each had 14 points, senior leader Bruce Thornton had 12, John Mobley Jr. added 13, and Amare Bynum chipped in with 10. Thornton has 1,787 career points, recently passed Jim Jackson for seventh in program history.

Head coach Jake Diebler is in his third season at Ohio State nad had led the team to a 36-22 record.

The Huskies protect the ball (10.8 turnovers per game is in the top 100 nationally) and shoot well at the line (77.7% on free throws), but field goal shooting is a major weakness. Washington are shooting 51.9% inside the 3-point line, which ranks 229th in the country.

Washington is on a two-game losing streak after falling 81-73 to No. 5 Purdue on the road Wednesday. Star freshman forward Hannes Steinbach (17 points, averaging 18.2 points and 11.2 rebounds per game) led four starters in double-figures as Washington rallied from a 17-point deficit behind Quimari Peterson (15 points), Zoom Diallo (14) and Franck Kepnang (10).

Head coach Danny Sprinkle is in his second season at Washington after winning the Mountain West regular title and an NCAA Tournament game with Utah State in 2023-24.

Where: Alaska Airlines Arena in Seattle, Washington

title: Why Portsmouth FA Cup return gives Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta the shivers – plus the latest on Kai Havertz
description: Arsenal return to Fratton Park for an FA Cup tie steeped in recent history, as Mikel Arteta prepares his side for a tricky trip to Portsmouth with memories of one of the most surreal nights of his man...
fullText:
Arsenal return to Fratton Park for an FA Cup tie steeped in recent history, as Mikel Arteta prepares his side for a tricky trip to Portsmouth with memories of one of the most surreal nights of his managerial career still lingering.

The last time Arteta stood in the Portsmouth dugout, in March 2020, football, and the world, was on the brink of shutting down. Arsenal won that evening en route to lifting the FA Cup later that summer, but for their head coach, the memory is a deeply personal one.

“I wasn’t feeling great, to be fair,” Arteta recalled. “The moment we scored, I was desperate to go home. I was shaking.” Within days, football would pause entirely as the Covid-19 pandemic took hold, making that night on the south coast an unlikely landmark at the start of an extraordinary period.

Four years on, Arsenal return as a far more established force, but Arteta is keen to stress that past achievements count for little as the current side continues its pursuit of silverware.

“We get judged for what we do today,” he said. “Last week is not important. We’ll be judged for what we’re able to do at the end of the season.”

That relentless focus underpins Arsenal’s approach to this season’s FA Cup, a competition Arteta famously won in his first year as a manager, albeit in virtually empty Wembley Stadium. The desire to lift trophies in front of supporters remains a powerful motivator.

“And the big ones as well,” he added. “That’s what we are chasing. That’s the purpose of this team.”

Team news ahead of the Portsmouth tie offers encouragement, particularly around Kai Havertz, who is closing in on a return for the first time this season. Arteta confirmed the forward has stepped up his training load and is responding well.

“If everything goes well, I think he’s going to be in the squad again in the next few days,” he said. “He trains well; he’s coping with that really well.”

Arteta was quick, however, to underline the standards awaiting any returning player. “When a player has the chance to put our shirt on and compete for us, the demands are excellence and that’s it.”

Rotation is likely with a heavy run of fixtures looming, including four away games across competitions in the coming weeks. Arteta acknowledged the need to manage minutes carefully, while still maintaining momentum.

“We have to make sure everybody is participating, we continue to perform and win games,” he said.

Goalkeeper Kepa Arrizabalaga, who has impressed in the League Cup, is among those pushing for a start, while Riccardo Calafiori is expected to miss out as the tie comes too soon in his recovery. There is also uncertainty around Piero Hincapie’s fitness after he was forced off against Liverpool on Thursday night, potentially opening the door further for Myles Lewis-Skelly to stake his claim.

“He’s playing and he’s doing well,” Arteta said. “He needs to continue to do that.”

title: Agent Of Inter Milan Target Says “It’s Nice” To Know Big Clubs Are Interested
description: Inter interest in Cagliari goalkeeper Elia Caprile has been publicly acknowledged by the player’s agent, who admits it is “nice” to know the Nerazzurri are watching closely.According to an inter...
fullText:
Inter interest in Cagliari goalkeeper Elia Caprile has been publicly acknowledged by the player’s agent, who admits it is “nice” to know the Nerazzurri are watching closely.

According to an interview with RAI Sport, Caprile’s agent Omar Rahman confirmed that Inter have been tracking the goalkeeper for some time.

“Inter’s interest? It’s nice to know that big clubs are following you,” Rahman said.

“Even when he was at Bari, Inter and Benfica had already made enquiries about Elia.”

The comments further underline Inter’s long-standing appreciation of the Verona-born shot-stopper, who has continued to grow since joining Cagliari.

CAGLIARI, ITALY – AUGUST 24: Elia Caprile of Cagliari in action during the Serie A match between Cagliari Calcio and ACF Fiorentina at Stadio Sant’Elia on August 24, 2025 in Cagliari, Italy. (Photo by Enrico Locci/Getty Images)

Caprile has impressed with his consistency and personality, establishing himself as a reliable presence between the posts despite his young age.

Inter’s interest is not merely theoretical.

As previously reported, the Nerazzurri are actively monitoring Caprile’s development and have recently sent a scout to observe him live.

The goalkeeper is viewed as a profile aligned with Inter’s future planning: young, Italian and financially accessible.

While there are no negotiations are currently underway.

However, the continued attention from Viale della Liberazione confirms Caprile’s status as one of the most closely followed goalkeepers in Serie A.

For now, Caprile remains focused on Cagliari, but the interest from Inter is firmly on record.

title: Toyota’s 2026 WEC objectives: Fix operational errors and win Le Mans again
description: Toyota has high expectations from the TR010 Hybrid as it enters the 2026 WEC
fullText:
Toyota has outlined its objectives for the 2026 World Endurance Championship, stating it wants to end its Le Mans 24 Hours victory drought and reduce operational errors.

Once the benchmark in the WEC’s top division, Toyota went the first seven rounds of the 2025 season without scoring a race win, before finally breaking through in the season finale in Bahrain.

It is now three years since the marque last won Le Mans and two since it claimed the drivers’ title, while 2025 marked the first time it didn’t win the manufacturers’ title in the Hypercar era.

But the Japanese manufacturer is aware of its shortcomings and has developed a heavily revised version of its Le Mans Hypercar, which was officially launched earlier this week under the TR010 Hybrid name.

It is the third major evolution of the car that originally debuted as the GR010 Hybrid in 2021, with a particular focus made on aerodynamics to maximise its speed under the Balance of Performance framework.

Toyota Racing vice-president Kazuki Nakajima admitted that the brand has been frustrated by its results at La Sarthe in recent years, but is confident the TR010 Hybrid can help reverse that trend.

“The biggest objective is clearly to win Le Mans,” Nakajima told Motorsport.com. “After three years of frustrating results in Le Mans, this is clearly the biggest target, as well as winning the championship, because we always look for these two big targets.

“But if I have to rate between two, I think Le Mans comes first priority.”

Toyota was long regarded as the strongest operational outfit in the WEC, often winning races through superior execution – even as competition intensified in the Hypercar era.

But the Cologne-based team’s usual clinical approach faltered on several occasions in 2025, as it tried to overcome what it felt was an unfavourable BoP at times.

The Lone Star Le Mans round proved particularly costly, with Toyota making a series of errors, including an ill-timed call to fit slick tyres on the #7 GR010 Hybrid while the track was still damp late in the race.

Nakajima admitted that the team hasn’t been on top of its game this year and has made addressing this weakness a priority for 2025.

“The team's execution like strategy, pit stop, drivers’ performance, not making mistakes and things like that, these are a big part of the performance factor in the race,” he said. “We just need to focus on this part.

Toyota reveals new-look WEC Hypercar for 2026 amid wider revamp

WEC Hypercar and IMSA GTP: Who is introducing updates in 2026 and who isn't?

“We have to admit that we have not been at the level that we are aiming for in terms of team execution this year [2025].

“In some races, we really performed well as a team but in some [other] races, we made mistakes. So, as a team we still need to improve ourselves, and this is a clear target for next year.”

To read more Motorsport.com articles visit our website.

title: Broncos focusing on the details preparing for Divisional Round playoff matchup
description: The Denver Broncos are focusing on the details and hoping last year’s playoff experience will have them better prepared this time around.
fullText:
We will know in just a few days who the Denver Broncos wind up playing in the 2026 NFL Playoff Divisional Round. Their 2025 regular season was a banner campaign. By notching fourteen wins, the Broncos are back to the top of the AFC West. Even better? They have the perks of a first-round playoff bye after securing the number one seed.

It wasn’t always pretty, but Denver showed a lot of toughness and tenacity this season. Embarking on multiple comeback wins, their penchant for fourth quarter comebacks coupled with a stellar defense propelled them to the best regular season record in the AFC in ‘25.

That’s something to be proud of. But now, everyone that made the postseason has a clean slate and an opportunity to etch their names into the NFL record books by winning Super Bowl 60. Everyone is back to square one.

In order for the Broncos to secure their fourth Lombardi Trophy, they will certainly need to work on the finer details. Over the course of the season, the Broncos struggled to be consistent—especially on the offensive side of the ball. Fixing that will be crucial in order for the Broncos to make a deep postseason push. Veteran right tackle Mike McGlinchey was vocal on what the team needed to address offensively to take care of business next weekend.

“First and foremost, the obvious thing is executing in the red zone. You have to turn field goals into touchdowns. That’s how you win games, especially this late in the year and especially as you go through the playoffs,” stated McGlinchey.

In addition to red zone performance, being better on a down-to-down basis was next up his list of things to address over the next week. I think all us fans can all agree slow starts were an issue for the Broncos this season. Their erratic and inconsistent performance across the board was one of the most frustrating aspects of an otherwise impeccable season.

“We have to be better on third down by being better on first and second down. It’s kind of a whole, as you go through these things, there are the ups and downs of the season. You just got to clean up the details, and we’ll be fine.”

🔙 to work.

👀 on the Divisional Round. pic.twitter.com/eN6SNec3lV

— Denver Broncos (@Broncos) January 9, 2026

One primary factor that has contributed to their lack of consistency has been penalties. Denver had plenty of during the regular season. On top of that, the Broncos were one of the teams that ranked highest in drops. It’s hard enough beating another team each and every weekend, but even more arduous by shooting yourself in the foot. By fixing those things, they should be able to hit their stride like McGlinchey is hoping for. If so, I’d be very optimistic about their chances next weekend—whoever they end up facing.

But it isn’t just cleaning up the finer details that the Broncos are working on. They’re also trying to learn from last year’s playoff experience as a tool to help put themselves in a better position this time around. Very few players on the roster last year had ever experienced the bright lights of the postseason.

With virtually most of their roster experiencing last season, Denver is certainly more experienced in 2026 and far more battle-tested to know what’s at stake next weekend. And the players know having a hometown crowd cheering them on will certainly be an advantage.

“That it’s a tournament for a reason. It’s do or die. I think last year, it was our first taste of it going into the playoffs as a Wild Card team, but now we have home-field advantage, which is different,” stated shutdown cornerback Patrick Surtain II.

Maybe I’m just bullish on Denver, but this year’s team just feels different. Better prepared, far more diligent, and a knack for gutting out close victories. That is something they hadn’t done in a very long time. They also seemed to play with a chip on their shoulder after all the preseason shade that was thrown their way.

The power of belief is a strong thing. For the most part, the Broncos had the right mindset and approach versus their opponents on a week-to-week basis. By harnessing this past years’ experience coupled with learning from last year’s early Wild Card Round exit, Denver should be better poised to weather whatever storm heads to Empower Field at Mile High next weekend.

“We have to definitely prep the right way and not take this thing for granted. Earlier on we talked about it, this is probably the last time that this whole team is going to be together, knowing how the league works. I feel like for this moment here, for all the marbles and stuff like that, we all have to buy in and understand that,” added Surtain.

title: Who will play in the 2026 Super Bowl? Here's what logo theory predicts
description: The Super Bowl is a month away, and everyone wants to know which two teams will play. Some say the Super Bowl logo predicts it. Here's what to know.
fullText:
As the 2026 Super Bowl creeps closer and closer, fans have started to make their predictions as to which two teams will play in the big game.

The Seattle Seahawks are the NFC's No. 1 seed, while the Denver Broncos are the AFC's No.1 seed. Yet there's a lot more to winning than just rankings; it takes team chemistry, skill and just the perfect amount of luck to make it to the Super Bowl.

However, some fans believe that none of that matters because the two teams playing in the big game can be predicted by the year's Super Bowl logo.

Here's the story behind the theory and what teams might be on the way to the Super Bowl.

The theory is that the colors included in that year's Super Bowl logo are the colors of the two teams that will play in the Super Bowl that year.

The theory came to be after fans started to notice that teams that made it to the big game had their colors incorporated into the big game logo for that year. The NFL Super Bowl logo is released a year before the big game, so there's no way anyone could accurately predict which teams would be playing each year.

So this isn't just an arbitrary theory, there is some evidence to it ... or coincidences, believers say.

For Super Bowl LVI in 2022, the logo featured red, orange and yellow tones. The two teams to play that year were the Los Angeles Rams, sporting blue and yellow uniforms, and the Cincinnati Bengals, wearing orange and black.

The logo for Super Bowl LVII in 2023, which was played in Glendale, shows a red-rock desert background with pink, teal and orangey-red colors. The two teams that played that year were the red Kansas City Chiefs and green Philadelphia Eagles, which are similar enough to the logo colors for the theory to continue.

However, the Super Bowl LVIII logo in 2024 featured a purple and pinkish-red color, which did not predict the showdown between the Chiefs and the 49ers, as both teams' colors are red and do not incorporate any purple. True believers of the conspiracy theory think this happened because the purple Baltimore Ravens had to be eliminated to make way for Travis Kelce's Chiefs and his pop-star girlfriend, Taylor Swift, to draw more fans to the big game.

The Super Bowl LIX logo in 2025 was green and red coloring to it, and once again, the Chiefs and Eagles played in the Super Bowl, keeping the theory alive.

🚨JUST IN: NBC HAS JUST ANNOUNCED THE OFFICIAL 2025 SUPER BOWL LOGO.

👀👀👀 

Wow… pic.twitter.com/Lr9JBjGURl

— MLFootball (@MLFootball) February 10, 2025

The logo for Super Bowl LX was revealed in February 2025 and features a multitude of bright colors, making it difficult to narrow down which team it could represent.

Pink and blue are the main colors featured in this year's brightly colored logo; however, since no teams have pink in their jerseys, the main colors to look for are blue, green, and yellow.

To narrow down what this could mean for the logo theory, here are some teams that incorporate those colors into their uniforms.

Out of that list, the teams that are currently still in the playoffs are: Denver Broncos, New England Patriots, Los Angeles Chargers, Jacksonville Jaguars, Buffalo Bills, Pittsburgh Steelers, Houston Texans, Seattle Seahawks, Chicago Bears, Green Bay Packers, Philadelphia Eagles, San Francisco 49ers, Carolina Panthers and Los Angeles Rams.

With all the differing colors and teams these colors could represent, there are many theories as to what this logo could mean.

The discord between logo theorists will continue until it's really revealed which two teams will play in the big game.

The Super Bowl LX is on Sunday, February 8, 2026, at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, California.

This article originally appeared on Arizona Republic: Who will play in the 2026 Super Bowl? What logo theory predicts

title: Notts County sign forward Enoru from Tamworth
description: Notts County sign forward Beck-Ray Enoru from National League side Tamworth for an undisclosed fee.
fullText:
Notts County have signed forward Beck-Ray Enoru from National League side Tamworth on a two-and-a-half-year deal for an undisclosed fee.

The 23-year-old helped the Lambs to promotion from National League North in 2024 after joining the Staffordshire club from Leicestershire non-league side Barwell.

Enoru, who arrived in England from Cameroon at the age of 16, now steps up to League Two with the "blessings" of those at Tamworth despite the Lambs being "disappointed" to lose a player that has been "a big part of the club's success".

Lambs boss Andy Peaks said offers came in during the summer and that Enoru has "decided now is the right time" to move.

Magpies director of football Richard Montague told the club website that Enoru has a "very exciting profile" and will "add another dimension" to Notts' attack.

title: Pat Surtain says Broncos feel 'very dangerous' going into NFL playoffs
description: "I feel like we are very dangerous knowing that we have home-field advantage right in front of us," Pat Surtain said going into the NFL playoffs.
fullText:
The Denver Broncos secured the No. 1 seed in the AFC playoffs after going 14-3 in the regular season. They now enter the NFL playoffs, and there's no room for error in the win-or-go-home format.

Last year, the Broncos made the playoffs for the first time since 2015, but they were promptly eliminated in the wild-card round. Now back in the postseason, they're looking to make a deep run with home-field advantage.

“It’s just a mindset, I believe," cornerback Pat Surtain said when asked what changes for a player in the playoffs. "We all realize in a tournament it’s do or die. It’s really almost zero margin of error once you’re in the tournament. We feel like, as a team we have a lot to correct and a lot to adjust, but at the end of the day, we are glad we have home-field advantage. You need as much of an advantage going into the playoffs. That’s a huge part of it, securing the No. 1 seed and getting home-field advantage. That’s big time for us. I feel like we aren’t a finished product. We aren’t where we want to be yet. Like I said before, I feel like we are very dangerous knowing that we have home-field advantage right in front of us.”

After a first-round bye, Denver will host the lowest advancing seed from the AFC in the divisional round next week. The Broncos will face either the Los Angeles Chargers (No. 7), Buffalo Bills (No. 6), Houston Texans (No. 5) or Pittsburgh Steelers (No. 4) on either Jan. 17 or Jan. 18. Denver will know its opponent and schedule by Monday evening.

Social: Follow Broncos Wire on Facebook and Twitter/X! Did you know: These 25 celebrities are Broncos fans.

title: Chiefs legend Dustin Colquitt named to Missouri Sports Hall of Fame
description: Kansas City Chiefs legend Dustin Colquitt named to the Missouri Sports Hall of Fame | @EdEastonJr
fullText:
The Kansas City Chiefs' legends continue to receive their praise well after their playing days have ended. The latest retired Chiefs star to be honored is long-time punter Dustin Colquitt, who was recently named to the Missouri Sports Hall of Fame class of 2026.

Colquitt, who will be enshrined on February 1st in Springfield, played the most games in franchise history and was a two-time Pro Bowler for Kansas City. He was a member of the Kansas City Super Bowl LIV championship team and recently officially retired with the franchise.

The former Tennessee Volunteer was selected by the Chiefs in the third round of the 2005 NFL Draft after his illustrious collegiate career. He spent 14 seasons in Kansas City before joining various teams in the final stretch of his career.

For 15 seasons, Colquitt experienced the franchise's highs and lows. In 238 regular-season games with the Chiefs, Colquitt tallied 1,167 punts and an impressive 477 inside the 20.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Chiefs legend Dustin Colquitt named to Missouri Sports Hall of Fame

title: Stephen Ross' legacy in balance with Miami Dolphins' next hire | Habib
description: Stephen Ross has a new GM (Jon-Eric Sullivan). If he can land John Harbaugh, it will redefine his ownership of the Miami Dolphins.
fullText:
Fourth-and-goal, 8-yard line, five seconds left in the Super Bowl, down by four. If that’s enough to make your palms sweaty, good.

If it’s enough to make Stephen Ross’ palms sweaty, even better.

Aaron Brewer is about to snap the ball to you, Steve. What you do with it will cement your legacy, that’s all. You’re not just cleaning house for the Miami Dolphins, but rebuilding it from the ground up. Get it right and much of the past 17 years becomes a footnote. Maybe not forgotten, but forgiven. They say this is a “what have you done for me lately?” world, so all you have to do is nail these hirings the way you have so often done in the business world.

Jon-Eric Sullivan is the new general manager. Within days, John Harbaugh will be the new head coach, at least if the collective will of South Florida has anything to say about it. Together they’ll represent a sweeping change the likes of which this franchise hasn’t undertaken in forever.

More Dolphins: New GM pledges Dolphins will be physical, tough and resilient. | Schad

If their results also produce sweeping change — if the Dolphins become relevant again this time of year — it will rewrite the book on Ross’ ownership of the Dolphins, which started in 2009. All those years of mediocrity. Of missing the playoffs. Of seeing coaches such as Joe Philbin come and Dan Campbell go. Of failing with the wrong quarterbacks and flailing at the right ones. Roll it into a ball and give Ross a pass if on fourth-and-goal, he seals the deal.

Ross said after last season that status quo was a no-go. He followed by firing general manager Chris Grier on Halloween and coach Mike McDaniel two days after the season. That’s how things go in the cutthroat world that is the NFL, although doubt creeps into one’s mind wondering if those fans celebrating their departures would do so if they actually knew either man. (Illegal use of sentiment, I know.)

We’re just getting to know Sullivan, who will be leaving his role as vice president of player personnel in Green Bay. He has spent 22 years in the Packers’ organization, so we know he’s loyal, experienced in making shrewd decisions and about to ditch his ice scraper. He learned from some of the best, including Ted Thompson and Brian Gutekunst. And he learned where his strengths lie.

“You’ve got to know who you are,” he said in a YouTube video on “The Unsung” while explaining why he’s not a coach. “I think I’m a better evaluator than I am a patient teacher.”

Trust your eyes more than your numbers. “Analytics are not going to supersede the film,” he said.

Don’t rely on other teams’ rejects. “You build through the draft,” he said. “It’s a young man’s game. You want to make sure you’re acquiring young, talented players that fit your culture. I think you experiment through free agency. … Those are dangerous waters to tread in all the time because teams typically aren’t moving from good players that are healthy and good in the locker room.”

Collaboration (that often-overused word inside the Dolphins’ facility) has its limits. “If we are all agreeing, nobody is thinking, you know what I mean?” he said. “If I’m a decision-maker and have a bunch of guys in the room tell me what I want to hear, that’s not very valuable to me.”

Whereas earning a wild-card spot has been cause for celebration in Miami, it’s nothing new to Sullivan. The Packers won the Super Bowl in 2010, a year after Ross took over the Dolphins. Green Bay qualified for this year’s playoffs, as it has all of the past seven seasons except one. That leaves Dolphins fans in a bind, knowing Sullivan’s hire looks smarter with each successive Packers victory, but each victory postpones when Sullivan can toss half his wardrobe and start fixing the Dolphins.

One more thing. Might as well address the elephant in the room: What’s with the hyphenated name?

“I’m still wondering about that,” Sullivan said. “I’m not sure why my parents did that to me. … At this point nobody calls me Jon. But nobody calls me Jon-Eric, either. It’s either J.E. or Sully, which I’m OK with, because Jon-Eric’s a lot to spit out. I don’t like introducing myself as Jon-Eric because I see people tilt their head and wonder, ‘Is this your first and middle name? Is this your whole first or last name?’ ”

That brings us to J.W. Harbaugh, better known as John.

No sense putting too much on reports that the Dolphins haven’t yet contacted him. Word is Harbaugh won’t begin sorting out his next chapter until next week. And so much of this business can be a matter of semantics. If Ross called an end-around and his people contacted Harbaugh’s people using the Cone of Silence buried inside a back channel, does that constitute “contact”? And while it would be nice for Harbaugh to know he’s very much wanted here, is there even the slightest chance, given Ross’ longstanding ties to the Harbaugh family, that a man as sharp as John doesn’t already know that?

The real pickle is what happens if Harbaugh’s next stop is elsewhere, say a team with a stable quarterback situation or a salary cap that isn’t drowning in red ink. Would Ross have fired McDaniel anyway? Would that bring, say, Jacksonville defensive coordinator Anthony Campanile back into the picture? Or has Ross had enough of first-time head coaches and does he go with Mike McCarthy?

We just witnessed quarterback Carson Beck carry the Miami Hurricanes into the end zone in a scenario not unlike the fourth-and-goal test Ross now faces.

There can be no question Ross will happily meet Harbaugh’s price.

Does he get to write the check, and with it, a new narrative on his ownership of the Dolphins?

This article originally appeared on Palm Beach Post: Dolphins' Stephen Ross hits legacy-defining moment on John Harbaugh

title: Colorado adds two intriguing lineman as transfer portal class grows
description: Colorado added a Sacramento State offensive lineman and a San Jose State defensive lineman, pushing the Buffs’ transfer portal class to 25 players.
fullText:
Colorado football added two linemen to its now 25-player deep transfer portal class. Former Sacramento State offensive lineman Jose Soto and San Jose State defensive lineman Vili Taufatofua have both committed to the Buffaloes.

Soto reunites with his former head coach, Colorado's new offensive coordinator, Brennan Marion. The 6-foot-3, 312-pounder was the Hornets' starting right guard in 2025. He did not allow a sack or quarterback hit in conference play. Soto provides depth along CU's offensive line as the Buffs' third offensive line transfer addition.

Taufatofua becomes Colorado's eighth commit on the defensive line. He is coming off an All-Mountain West Honorable Mention season where he racked up 34 tackles, seven tackles for loss, three sacks, two forced fumbles and one pass breakup. He started in 11 games last season.

The New Zealand native began his FBS career at Utah but did not see any action. He is the seventh projected edge rusher that the Buffs added, signalling a clear plan to improve the defensive line and, more specifically, the pass rush.

Let’s Work! Go Buffs 🦬#Commited pic.twitter.com/eaf6AfpZ0T

— Vili Taufatofua (@ViliTaufatofua) January 10, 2026

Taufatofua and Soto continue the trend of Colorado adding highly productive lower-level players. The strategy is sound, especially after a 3-9 season, and one Sanders believes in.

title: 'The goal of the game?' A sportswriter dives into youth sports mania
description: Former New York Times writer Harvey Araton's novel reveals a raucous life of a youth athlete, and lessons we can all learn from it.
fullText:
It’s a statement but also a question we can ask ourselves as sports parents.

It’s driven into our kids very early, often by us.

Or is it to just enjoy the experience?

“Dad, according to Mom, asked the parents in our group not to worry about how good we were, or weren’t,” writes author Harvey Araton, through the eyes of a kid named “Z,” in a new middle-grade novel.

Z’s dad was the coach of the boy’s first soccer team. It’s a neighborhood collection of grade school buddies. Dad didn’t just roll out the ball, though. He orchestrated drills that mimicked game situations that gave everyone a shot at the action.

“You scrimmage too much, and the same kids, the stronger players, will dominate the ball, and then how do the other kids get better?” Z overhears his dad telling his mom early in the book.

Everyone notices, in fiction and reality, when others don’t have this growth mentality.

Z and his teammates hear opposing parents scream for blood, or at least a foul, when his team, once a doormat, incrementally starts to get better and begins to dominate.

The kids of manic youth sports parents, one of whom Araton admits to once being himself, is whom he wants to reach. The veteran sportswriter, most recently with The New York Times for 25 years, covered the Danny Almonte age scandal at the 2001 Little League World Series, and the ensuing escalation of Little League World Series coverage into American living rooms.

He has pondered or written about (or both) kids choosing between club and high school soccer and early sports specialization.

He also played the role of sports dad to two now-grown sons (36 and 32).

“Kids learn playing sports,” Araton tells USA TODAY Sports. “I think there's a joy in that. I just feel, especially at these early years, it's becoming infected with this ambition that there could be a pot of gold at the end of the rainbow and I think too many parents become obsessed with turning their children into potential cash machines.”

Araton launched the book last week with a signing at his local bookstore in Montclair, New Jersey. He made sure to also include a panel discussion about youth sports. He spoke with us about how his novel imitates the raucous life America lives within it, and the lessons he has gleaned from it.

YOUTH SPORTS SURVIVAL GUIDE: Pre-order Coach Steve's upcoming book for young athletes and their parents

Araton is from Staten Island, which he describes as New York City’s last developed borough. It still has large swaths of parks and fields, where his story is set.

He had grown up on the basketball courts near his public housing development. The free play felt natural as it took him to the local Jewish community center and high school. He eventually played at a health club in Brooklyn as an adult and even worked in Madison Square Garden, where he covered the Knicks, the team he had idolized as a kid.

His competitive juices carried him into fatherhood when his older son, Alex, was in first grade and had the option of going out for a travel team. It’s a decision many of us have faced.

“I remember asking him if he wanted to try out,” Araton says. “And he was kind of a naturally cautious kid and said, ‘Not really,’ and I remember being disappointed, a little deflated. Maybe I already was thinking, ‘If he doesn't go into this next level, he'll fall behind and never catch up, (and) there will go any chance of playing in high school.’ I mean, I could look at my kids, look at their size even at that age and know that they weren't likely to be D1 college athletes.

“But I remember being disappointed and over the next couple of weeks, I came up with five or six different ways to pose the same question. Well, Nick's trying out, you sure you don't want (to)? And he kept saying no. And then the last time that I asked, he said, ‘No, dad.’ And then he looked at me and said, ‘But if I don't play travel, can I still play in the town league?’

“And I remember feeling this sensation of shame because I realized in that moment that I was projecting my own ambitions and my own sports values onto this 6-year-old kid. And all he wanted to do at that point in his life was just run around and play with a bunch of kids he knew and maybe take one or two things out of any game and feel good about himself and look forward to the snacks.”

The book’s central character, who tells the story in the first person, is a combination of Araton’s two sons. Charly, Alex’s younger brother, was 4-foot-11 when he entered high school but played on the basketball team for four years.

Z is left-footed with really good field vision like Alex and he’s small and feisty like Charly was. It doesn’t seem to bother Z when his young team is losing because he knows he will celebrate the things they all did well, or at least enjoyed, at Big Mitch’s restaurant afterward.

Big Mitch is the father of his friend and teammate, Lloyd.

“You only let in, like, seven or eight goals on an undefeated travel team,” he tells Lloyd, the team’s goalie, in the book. “Do you think a kid who was out of shape could do that?”

Z becomes less comfortable when sports becomes more and more competitive. His father has a horrific accident and the team eventually gets a coach from England, who adopts a similar skills-first mindset with the kids. Kevin, the coach, who has also had a traumatic experience with his father, takes Z under his wing.

As the boys and girls on the team continue to rise in competition level, and travel further and further away from Staten Island, Z gets a much more transactional coach.

He feels himself immersed in a world over which he has less and less control, similar to the experiences Araton observed and felt as a soccer dad.

“The reason why I chose soccer is because I probably was most closely involved with that, whether it was as coaching them in the early grades or just being at the games and kind of like, living for it a little bit,” he says. “I understand why parents are so heavily involved. After a week of work you really look forward to the experience of the games. It's like an adrenaline rush but also I think, it created a whole social network with the parents of their teammates and friends and everything. So I get the temptation, and the seductiveness, of it all, but (it) all got completely out of control, as well.”

Youth sports 'crisis': Congress addresses big business in youth sports. Can we fix it?

While Araton was growing up on Staten Island, the borough’s Mid-Island Little League won it all in Williamsport. Years later, as a sportswriter, Araton caught up with Danny Yaccarino, who came within one strike of a perfect game during that 1964 Little League World Series against Monterrey, Mexico.

He wrote a column, (‘After Perfection at the Age of 12, What's Next?’) detailing how Yaccarino became a very good high school pitcher and reached the Baltimore Orioles organization and yet, he was always haunted by the feeling of coming so close to near-perfection as a Little Leaguer and not getting it.

“Not only did he get a lot of bench jockeying and all that stuff throughout his career, but he also put incredible pressure on himself,” Araton says. “He turned out to be a minor league pitcher and he never went very far. But he told me that he finished his career feeling like an abject failure.”

Z feels an emptiness, too, at the climax of the book. It's a feeling that can be induced by us.

"Parents, being vulnerable, and easily manipulated into spending vast sums of money, (wind) up treating their children like they are speculating on a stock, an investment," Araton says. "They're not stocks that will pay off at 8 or 9 or 10 years; they're developing human beings."

“Z, we’re running behind,” his mother yells upstairs, trying to get him moving for his U-13 fall season-opening game. She’s now the team’s driven parent-manager.

“The construction of this story is really about Z coming to an understanding of what role sports should play in his life,” Araton says. “And when I say that, I mean, at that particular time, kids are always subject to change. He's at a point in his life where he's experienced family trauma, and, when he looks around, he doesn't see the friends who he loves, the kids that he grew up playing with. He sees a lot of strange kids. And that's not what he wants. More than playing at an elite level, he wants to play with kids who know him, who know what he's gone through.

“He realizes that he still loves the game, but will only play it under his terms.”

Isn’t that what we all want? What about our kids, too?

“You could offer them the higher-level stuff,” Araton says, “but if it's being forced upon them, and if you're calling up to their bedroom every time there's practice, then it's clear that they don't really want to do it.

“I wouldn't deny an exceptional child that kind of pathway any more than you would, say, if you had a child who (was) a mathematical genius or a classical violinist, you would want them to have the best teachers to best capitalize on their special talent. But the temptation is so great because sports is the most visible thing in the community. …

"It'll become pretty obvious to a parent if they have someone special. But this whole notion that they can create one by spending significant sums of money, I think it's really overstated.”

Araton points to another interview he did, with Yael Averbuch, the general manager of the New Jersey/New York Gotham FC of the National Women's Soccer League (NWSL). She played for an exclusive club team in high school, won two national championships playing for the University of North Carolina and was drafted professionally.

Her mother said she never had to yell upstairs for practice. Yael was the one yelling to them.

Araton’s sons, like Z, had to figure out where sports fit into their lives. It worked out for them, too.

Alex, who played high school soccer, is a special education teacher and Charly, the high school basketball player (who has grown to about 5-foot-9 today), works in marketing strategies for a fashion brand. He still plays in men’s leagues.

Araton says those middle-grade age groups – 8 to 12, give or take – are the ages where people know the least amount about who their children are as athletes.

“Don’t be disappointed if at the age of 8, they are not willing to do all this stuff and make all that sacrifice,” he says. “They might be ready when they're 11. Kids do things on their own time schedules. So just accept who they are and let them experience sports in the way they want to. They’ll enjoy it more and get more out of it.

“If they're not playing for the idea of feeling good about themselves, about learning to be a coachable kid, and be a good teammate, to play with kids from all different backgrounds and develop their skills at the fundamental level at the age of 7, 8, 9, 10,” Araton says, “then they're playing for the wrong reasons.

“Each shall develop at their own rate. I just think that parents have to chill and let the kids experience it for themselves.”

Borelli, aka Coach Steve, has been an editor and writer with USA TODAY since 1999. He spent 10 years coaching his two sons’ baseball and basketball teams. He and his wife, Colleen, are now sports parents for two high schoolers. His Coach Steve column is posted weekly. For his past columns, click here.

Got a question for Coach Steve you want answered in a column? Email him at sborelli@usatoday.com

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: 'The goal of the game?' It's a question sports parents can ask

title: A new transfer running back has emerged as a Texas A&M target
description: Texas A&M is reportedly eyeing Michigan State transfer RB Makhi Frazier, but Baylor transfer back Bryson Washington remains in the mix.
fullText:
Texas A&M's 2026 running back room could feature a new face from the transfer portal, and while Baylor transfer back Bryson Washington made his way to College Station this weekend, Washington is now in the mix for the Texas native, which have have made a significant push this week. However, this doesn't rule out the Aggies landing a transfer running back, as a new name has emerged.

According to AggieYell insider Jaxson Callaway, Texas A&M is now targeting Michigan State transfer running back Makhi Frazier, who is reportedly coming off a Friday visit to Ohio State. While this may seem daunting, the Aggies have won multiple transfer battles against the Buckeyes this month. Still, adding another running back isn't A&M's top priority compared to other programs.

Washington is still the No. 1 running back target for head coach Mike Elko and his staff, and Callaway is right to state that the rest of the RB portal market will depend on Washington's choice regarding which way the Huskies will go.

"At the moment, much of the running back market appears to be waiting on Washington’s decision."

Focusing on Frazier, the McKinney, Texas native is listed at 5'10" and nearly 220 pounds, and is coming off an impressive 2025 sophomore campaign after rushing for 520 yards and two touchdowns, averaging 4.5 yards per carry.

Per Pro Football Focus, Frazier earned a solid offensive grade (74.8) and a rushing grade (77.6), which bodes well for his future as a potential starting or No. 2 running back. Frazier will continue to be a name to watch, but until Bryson Washington makes his decision, both players will be the top backs on the Aggies' radar.

title: Joel Embiid talks Sixers' win over Magic, rewarding feeling of playing
description: Joel Embiid discusses the win for the Philadelphia 76ers over the Orlando Magic as well as the rewarding feeling of playing again.
fullText:
ORLANDO, Fla. -- The Philadelphia 76ers picked up an important 103-91 win over the Orlando Magic on Friday night. Not only did the win keep the winning vibes going for Philadelphia as it has won five of its last six games, but the win secured the all-important tiebreaker for the Sixers as they clinched the season series 2-1 over the Magic.

The win also pushed Philadelphia a game and a half ahead of the Magic in the standings. Everything in the Eastern Conference is so bunched up, and even though it's still early in the season, every win counts and it's important for the Sixers to win these types of games.

"It's still early in the season," said Joel Embiid who finished with 22 points and nine rebounds in the win. "It's kind of hard to start thinking about tie breaks and all that, but it's good. Obviously, we’re right there with them. Our aim is to keep winning and keep climbing up the standings, and they happen to do the same thing, and if that's needed. I guess that's a good thing."

Speaking of Embiid, he played in his sixth straight game on Friday. It's the first time the big fella has played in six straight games was from Jan. 15, 2024 to Jan. 25, 2024. It's a big leap for Embiid as the 2023 MVP winner continues to get his rhythm and get back on track as a player.

"Yeah, it feels good," Embiid smiled after the win. "That's why, even with fatigue that you're feeling from your body getting used to it's just that fact of just being on the floor and playing basketball. That just makes me so happy."

Embiid's main thing when asked about his availability all season has been "gotta keep it going" as he brushes off the idea of playing in so many consecutive games as some big deal. However, he thought about it and realized how much of a big step this is for him.

"Obviously, one thing I learned, especially the last two years being in this moment, I enjoy it," Embiid added. "I know I usually say, ‘Oh, got to keep building on it,' but this is a moment where I'm like, I'm sure maybe not of a lot of people out there never thought this would happen again. So, got to keep playing and put in the work to keep that going."

With that being said, this hasn't been a walk in the park for Embiid. The big fella is certainly feeling it in the middle of playing so many games after so much time off.

"I feel OK, physically," he finished. "It was one of those nights that I haven't been two or three years playing as much. So, I kind of felt it before the game and start the game, but you push through it. That's how you get better. You get used. You get used to it that grind again."

Embiid and the Sixers will finish this quick 3-game trip with a back-to-back against the Toronto Raptors on Sunday and Monday.

This article originally appeared on Sixers Wire: Joel Embiid talks Sixers' win over Magic, rewarding feeling of playing

title: Notre Dame had its first transfer commit, then didn’t 45-minutes later
description: Notre Dame football still is looking for its first transfer commit, as they were teased on Friday, but ultimately didn’t sign anyone.
fullText:
It has been a very weird transfer portal window for Notre Dame football, and the oddness continued on Friday afternoon.

Colorado defensive back DJ McKinney committed to the Irish, but shortly after that announcement was made, multiple sources reported that the verbal has been rescinded. At this moment, there is not much more information out on what transpired between the Irish and McKinney, but something clearly happened.

The portal has been open a week, and Notre Dame is still waiting on its first addition. There is still another week remaining for players to enter, so more options will emerge. You have to assume that the Irish will make stronger pushes for players during the second half of the window.

Hard to say what comes next, but Notre Dame will continue to host players as they try to find the right fit for the program.

DJ McKinney’s signed status with Notre Dame has been rescinded, @mzenitz and I have learned. https://t.co/vEZfCjlHpB

— Chris Hummer (@chris_hummer) January 9, 2026
